sentences.sentence: Global perspective Joe Biden sought at his inauguration last year to reunify Americans.

The US midterm elections demonstrate how hard that task is proving to be.If anyone had any doubts about the degree of hyperpartisanship in the United States, the latest United States Studies Centre research on public opinion in the US fully captures the immense divisiveness engulfing the country.The top four issues for Joe Biden voters: Reducing gun violence.
Dealing with climate change.
Improving education.
Protecting abortion rights.The top four issues for Donald Trump voters: Reducing inflation.
Dealing with immigration.
Reducing crime.

Improving education.The top three Trump voter issues do not coincide with any of the top four Democratic voter priorities.As we get closer to election day next Tuesday, the polling from the field is clear: it is the economy and its related issues - inflation, petrol prices, rising interest rates - that are the primary concern of all voters surveyed.The mantra on which Bill Clinton rode into the White House in 1992 - "It's the economy, stupid" - is also governing these midterm elections.Clinton proved - and Biden certainly understands from what he and Barack Obama suffered politically during the Great Recession more than a decade ago - that it is the president who is seen by most Americans as owning the economy and how it is performing.Obama lost 63 Democratic House seats in the 2010 midterms.

The Federal Reserve has delivered another interest rate hike to home owners and businesses one week before election day, and it will continue the hurt Americans are feeling when they reach for their wallets.Because the voters overall are telling us that reducing inflation and reducing crime are their two top concerns, we can trust the on-the-ground reporting from the campaigns as journalists and experts assay the races under way that the Republican campaigns for the House of Representatives and the Senate are effectively pushing these economy and culture war issue buttons.The Democrats have been hoping that, after the Supreme Court decision striking down a woman's constitutional right to access abortion services (Roe v Wade), the anger over that issue would drive a Democratic wave.It will certainly be helpful in many races, especially for the Senate, where several extremist Republican candidates want to outlaw abortion altogether.

But the United States Study Centre polling is clear: protecting abortion rights only ranks seventh in terms of importance among all voters.This is not only a terribly partisan time, it is a terribly discouraging time in terms of how Americans assess their own country, their democracy, and its future.Nearly two-thirds of Americans are "very concerned" about the way democracy is working - which means that in their eyes it is not working properly; 71 per cent are very concerned about Congress' ability to do its job; 57 per cent are very concerned about the lack of compromise between Democrats and Republicans; 70 per cent are very concerned about misinformation.

Half are fearful of potential political violence.America's voters are deeply troubled.Two-thirds of both Biden and Trump voters are equally concerned about how democracy is working, and even more are concerned with the ability of Congress to do its job.
But we can be certain that they hold this common view for different reasons.Biden voters fear the extremism presented by Trump and his base and his allies in Congress.

Republican voters fear the "woke" political and social agenda of Democrats.The US government is not working properly any more, and the voters surveyed by United States Study Centre are reflecting this reality.Biden wanted to be the leader who would end this American divide and bring the country together.In his inaugural address in last year, Biden said: "Today, on this January day, my whole soul is in this: bringing America together.
Uniting our people.
And uniting our nation.
"I ask every American to join me in this cause.
Uniting to fight the common foes we face.
Anger, resentment, hatred.
Extremism, lawlessness, violence.
Disease, joblessness, hopelessness.
"With unity we can do great things.
Important things.

"The United States Study Centre polling reflects a strong view that the president has not succeeded in advancing national unity.The polling also reveals little confidence that Biden or Trump can lift the country up and take it forward.Only 35 per cent of American voters believe it would be good or very good if Biden won a second term.Only 40 per cent believe the same about Trump - a slightly bigger margin, but still considerably less than half the country.The overall portrait presented in this research signals that America's malaise will continue.

If Republicans gain the House or Senate, Biden's domestic legislative agenda will be dead on arrival on Capitol Hill.If Republicans pass extremist bills, they will be met with a Biden veto.The rifts and doubts across America will deepen.Happy days are not here again.Bruce Wolpe is a senior non-resident fellow at the United States Studies Centre at the University of Sydney.
He previously served on the Democratic Party staff in the US Congress and as chief of staff to former prime minister Julia Gillard.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
documents.inputText: Global perspective Joe Biden sought at his inauguration last year to reunify Americans. The US midterm elections demonstrate how hard that task is proving to be.If anyone had any doubts about the degree of hyperpartisanship in the United States, the latest United States Studies Centre research on public opinion in the US fully captures the immense divisiveness engulfing the country.The top four issues for Joe Biden voters: Reducing gun violence. Dealing with climate change. Improving education. Protecting abortion rights.The top four issues for Donald Trump voters: Reducing inflation. Dealing with immigration. Reducing crime. Improving education.The top three Trump voter issues do not coincide with any of the top four Democratic voter priorities.As we get closer to election day next Tuesday, the polling from the field is clear: it is the economy and its related issues - inflation, petrol prices, rising interest rates - that are the primary concern of all voters surveyed.The mantra on which Bill Clinton rode into the White House in 1992 - "It's the economy, stupid" - is also governing these midterm elections.Clinton proved - and Biden certainly understands from what he and Barack Obama suffered politically during the Great Recession more than a decade ago - that it is the president who is seen by most Americans as owning the economy and how it is performing.Obama lost 63 Democratic House seats in the 2010 midterms. The Federal Reserve has delivered another interest rate hike to home owners and businesses one week before election day, and it will continue the hurt Americans are feeling when they reach for their wallets.Because the voters overall are telling us that reducing inflation and reducing crime are their two top concerns, we can trust the on-the-ground reporting from the campaigns as journalists and experts assay the races under way that the Republican campaigns for the House of Representatives and the Senate are effectively pushing these economy and culture war issue buttons.The Democrats have been hoping that, after the Supreme Court decision striking down a woman's constitutional right to access abortion services (Roe v Wade), the anger over that issue would drive a Democratic wave.It will certainly be helpful in many races, especially for the Senate, where several extremist Republican candidates want to outlaw abortion altogether. But the United States Study Centre polling is clear: protecting abortion rights only ranks seventh in terms of importance among all voters.This is not only a terribly partisan time, it is a terribly discouraging time in terms of how Americans assess their own country, their democracy, and its future.Nearly two-thirds of Americans are "very concerned" about the way democracy is working - which means that in their eyes it is not working properly; 71 per cent are very concerned about Congress' ability to do its job; 57 per cent are very concerned about the lack of compromise between Democrats and Republicans; 70 per cent are very concerned about misinformation. Half are fearful of potential political violence.America's voters are deeply troubled.Two-thirds of both Biden and Trump voters are equally concerned about how democracy is working, and even more are concerned with the ability of Congress to do its job. But we can be certain that they hold this common view for different reasons.Biden voters fear the extremism presented by Trump and his base and his allies in Congress. Republican voters fear the "woke" political and social agenda of Democrats.The US government is not working properly any more, and the voters surveyed by United States Study Centre are reflecting this reality.Biden wanted to be the leader who would end this American divide and bring the country together.In his inaugural address in last year, Biden said: "Today, on this January day, my whole soul is in this: bringing America together. Uniting our people. And uniting our nation."I ask every American to join me in this cause. Uniting to fight the common foes we face. Anger, resentment, hatred. Extremism, lawlessness, violence. Disease, joblessness, hopelessness."With unity we can do great things. Important things."The United States Study Centre polling reflects a strong view that the president has not succeeded in advancing national unity.The polling also reveals little confidence that Biden or Trump can lift the country up and take it forward.Only 35 per cent of American voters believe it would be good or very good if Biden won a second term.Only 40 per cent believe the same about Trump - a slightly bigger margin, but still considerably less than half the country.The overall portrait presented in this research signals that America's malaise will continue. If Republicans gain the House or Senate, Biden's domestic legislative agenda will be dead on arrival on Capitol Hill.If Republicans pass extremist bills, they will be met with a Biden veto.The rifts and doubts across America will deepen.Happy days are not here again.Bruce Wolpe is a senior non-resident fellow at the United States Studies Centre at the University of Sydney. He previously served on the Democratic Party staff in the US Congress and as chief of staff to former prime minister Julia Gillard.
